channel.title: People on Dynamics of Language Lab
channel.description: Recent content in People on Dynamics of Language Lab

item.title: Omrimayraz
item.description: Omri Mayraz is an MA student of linguistics in the joint direct PhD program of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Tel Aviv University. He studies phenomena at the syntax-semantics interface with a focus on negation from a typological and diachornic perspective. He is also interested in Persian and Kurdish. A direct PhD scholar.

item.title: Mayainbar
item.description: I am a graduate student in the Department of Linguistics, and have earned my B.A. in Linguistics and Cognitive Science and M.A. in Linguistics both at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. My current research projects are co-supervised by Dr. Eitan Grossman and Dr. Ayelet Landau from the CogSci & Psychology departments, and in them I apply analysis methods from the study of rhythmic neural activity to learn about temporal structure in language use.

item.title: Shiratal
item.description: Shira has a B.A. degree in Cognitive Science and Philosophy and a M.A. degree in Cognitive Science, both from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. She is interested in language acquisition and language change. Her PhD research is focused on the ways by which languages are shaped by learning and communication constraints. Using psycholinguistic experiments and corpus studies, she aims to tease apart the influence of different cognitive pressures on the linguistic input.

item.title: Head of the Lab
item.description: I am an assistant professor in the Department of Linguistics and the School of Language Sciences at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem since 2012. In 2013, I was appointed a member of the interdisciplinary Language, Logic and Cognition Center. Before this, I was a postdoctoral researcher in the Ramses Project (and later a Visiting Professor) at the University of Li√®ge, a Kreitman Fellow at Ben Gurion University of the Negev, and spent 2010-2012 at the Martin Buber Society of Fellows in Jerusalem.
